title: Ethics and Moral Philosophy Lexicon
description: Specialized vocabulary for ethical theory and moral philosophy

items.definition: Ethical theory that judges actions based on adherence to rules or duties rather than consequences
items.example: Kantian deontology holds that certain acts are intrinsically wrong regardless of their outcomes.

items.definition: The view that actions should be judged solely by their consequences
items.example: Act consequentialism evaluates individual actions; rule consequentialism evaluates rules for action.

items.definition: Kant's supreme principle of morality: act only according to rules you could will as universal laws
items.example: The categorical imperative forbids using persons merely as means to ends.

items.definition: Beyond what is required by duty; morally praiseworthy but not obligatory
items.example: Heroic self-sacrifice is typically considered supererogatory rather than obligatory.

items.definition: The view that moral principles cannot be stated in general terms; each situation requires unique judgment
items.example: Moral particularism challenges the search for universal ethical principles.

items.definition: Acting against one's better judgment; weakness of will
items.example: Akrasia presents a puzzle: how can we knowingly act against our own perceived good?

items.definition: The study of the nature, foundations, and meaning of ethical statements themselves
items.example: Metaethics asks whether moral statements can be true or false, and what makes them so.

items.definition: The phenomenon that factors beyond our control affect moral judgment of our actions
items.example: The concept of moral luck challenges the assumption that we are only responsible for what we control.
